name: 2G/3G/4G
description: 2nd, 3rd and 4th Generation. These are generic names for the evolutionary stages of wireless telephone technology.

name: 3rd Party Tag
description: These come in several forms, including 'Image Tags', 'JavaScript Tags', and 'Click Tags'. The most common and basic type is an image tag, which is a 1x1 clear pixel incorporated into a web page by a browser when it renders the page for a user. This pixel lets the third party ad server know that an action has been taken by the user. A cookie is also sent with this pixel, and this enables the third party ad server to confirm that the action has been taken as a result of marketing activity on the media owner's site. It also enables the third party to cross-reference the user with users who clicked on or viewed the advertising.

name: ABC
description: The Audit Bureau of Circulations (ABC) is the industry body whose wide-ranging duties and services include the following:↵+ Measuring reach↵+ Measuring engagement and loyalty↵+ Upholding common standards for how digital measurement is prepared and reported↵+ Creating best practice guidelines for digital measurement↵+ Accreditation of digital service providers.

name: Above The Fold
description: The ‘fold’ of a website refers to the line of transition created by the bottom of a user’s screen when first viewing a web page. Anything below the fold requires the user to scroll down in order to view it. Content below the fold cannot contribute to a user’s initial decision whether to stay on a page and engage with the content. Ads placed prominently above the fold on a website are more likely to adversely impact user experience.

name: Accelerometer
description: The accelerometer is a sensor in a mobile device which measures the tilting motion and orientation of the device. For instance, when the screen is tilted horizontally, such as when reading a web-page in a landscape view, the technology detects orientation change and rotates the screen accordingly in order to optimise the viewing experience for the user.

name: Accountability
description: Being able to attribute actual success to specific marketing and advertising efforts.

name: Ad impression/ad view
description: A single ad that appears on a web page. Because several ads often appear on the same web page, the number of registered ad impressions will almost always outstrip the number of page impressions.

name: Ad Inventory
description: The amount of advertising space available at any given supply-side source.

name: Ad Network
description: A platform that aggregates the inventory of lots of different media owners to sell to the buy-side, with pricing based on each website's audience profile.

name: Ad Rank
description: Equation which determines the position of bidders' ads in the AdWords auction. Ad Rank is calculated using the following formula: Maximum Bid x Quality Score = Ad Rank.

name: Ad server
description: A specialised web server dedicated to hosting and delivering online advertisements on request.

name: Ad Verification
description: A service which enables advertisers to confirm that their ads have been delivered into their intended content.

name: Ad Yield
description: The amount of money generated by an ad placement, after costs.

name: AdSense Custom Search Ads
description: AdSense feature which enables each search on independent search provider sites (e.g. price comparison sites, travel specialists, etc.) to display targeted Google search ads.

name: Adstock
description: Adstock is a simple mathematical model used to calculate the lagged effect of advertising on a consumer (i.e. the amount of time people remember a campaign for in the weeks after it’s been active). Different types of media have different average adstock or, in measuring terms, ‘advertising carry-over rates’, depending on how impactful and memorable they are.

name: Advertiser Funded
description: The traditional funding model for free-to-air television channels such as ITV, Channel 4 and Channel 5. Viewers do not pay to watch content. Instead, the broadcaster funds content production through advertising revenue.

name: Advertiser Funded Programming
description: The traditional funding model for free-to-air television channels such as ITV, Channel 4 and Channel 5. Viewers do not pay to watch content. Instead, the broadcaster funds content production through advertising revenue, including sponsorships, product placement, naming rights, or even the production of entire programmes.

name: AEM
description: The Adobe Experience Manager or AEM is a content management system and the central Unilever hub of owned engagement with consumers online. It is integrated with the Digital 2.0 Ecosystem of tools (PIM TAB, RMS).

name: Algorithm
description: The individual calculations that a search engine uses to determine search rankings. SEO literature often refers to individual algorithm updates with names such as ‘Panda’ or ‘Penguin’. These algorithms are undocumented and constantly updated and are therefore a major source of uncertainty for SEO practitioners.

name: Alt text
description: A text label composed in HTML that is assigned to a visual or non-textual element. It is displayed to users when the non-textual element (e.g. a photo) cannot be rendered by the browser for some reason.

name: Analytics
description: Tools and practices that allow marketers to assess and measure factors such as consumer behaviour, ad performance and campaign performance. Running analytics across campaigns allows you to use data to attempt to form a competitive advantage.

name: Anchor text
description: The human readable element of a hyperlink that redirects users to a new web page. The URL for the new web page is embedded in the text to make it a clickable link, but the text itself is not usually the URL. Instead, it is usually a description of the page it links to of no more than 60 characters. It usually appears as a clickable element of a piece of textual content that is of a noticeably different colour to the rest of the text. A descriptive tooltip may appear over the anchor text if you hover over it with your cursor.

name: API
description: Application Programming Interface. This is a programming technology that allows two or more web-based software applications to exchange information with each other without user involvement. When sites like Facebook and Amazon release an API, it allows third-party web developers to access information and functions from those sites and integrate them into their own applications.  Facebook's Open Graph API is the most famous example.

name: Application (App)
description: Previously, these were just software applications designed to help users perform specific tasks. The concept is now most closely associated with mobile. It refers to any number of applications that can be bought or downloaded for free from a variety of distribution platforms, such as Apple's App Store or the Google Play store.

name: Attribution Modelling
description: The process, technology or combination thereof that allows advertisers to assess which mix of ads are most effective, or have resulted in specific actions along the user journey.

name: Attribution studies
description: See entry for 'clickpath analysis'.

name: Audience Extension
description: A technique used by media owners to increase their reach by targeting their audiences across different (external) sites - usually a closed group of similar sites.

name: Awareness
description: Building awareness is predominantly a brand advertising objective. In the online environment, measuring awareness involves issuing pop up surveys to two groups, one of which has seen the advertising and one that hasn't. Members of the group that have seen the ad are identified by cookies. The survey then asks questions designed to measure awareness uplift in the group that has seen the ad by comparing their responses with those of the control group that hasn't seen the ad.

name: Backrub
description: The student research project undertaken by Larry Page and Sergey Brin which analysed the link structure of the World Wide Web. Using the academic citation system as their inspiration, the two men devised the PageRank algorithm to ascribe a quantitative quality metric to websites based on the number and quality of backlinks they attract. Backrub laid the foundations for Google, the world's largest and most profitable search engine.

name: Baidu
description: China's most popular search engine (ranked the 5th most popular site worldwide by Alexa) founded by Robin Li and Eric Xu and launched in October 1999. It has enjoyed exponential advertising-funded growth over the years, and like Google it has significantly diversified its offering. Baidu currently offers social networking, encyclopaedias, internet TV, a browser, online communities, and a smartphone operating system. The company launched its own smartphone, the Changhong H5018, in 2012. It has come under fire internationally for its alleged acquiescence to Chinese government content censorship requests.

name: Banner Ad
description: A simple and prevalent online ad format, usually in the form of a rectangular image and appearing at the top of a page.

name: Banner Blindness
description: Banner blindness is a particular phenomenon in online advertising, describing the tendency for website visitors to consciously or subconsciously ignore banner ads or any other banner-like elements on a web page.

name: BARB
description: The Broadcasters Audience Research Board (BARB) provides official data on UK television viewing figures.

name: Behavioural targeting
description: A method whereby users can be presented with advertising targeted to them according to their online behaviour. The first step in this method is categorising users by their online habits using cookies. This can be achieved by encouraging users to perform actions in specific site sections, such as newsletter registrations, competition entries, etc. If there is a consistent pattern to the site sections the user visits, this can be used to build a behavioural profile. Owning multiple sites is a clear advantage with this method, particularly if they have features in common, e.g. sports sections. Blind networks can also build large behavioural groups because of the number of sites they work across. The second step is to serve ads to these groups that reflect their online interests/behaviour. Because the profile has been built behaviourally using cookies, relevant ads can be served to the user anywhere on the site, not just in the sections to which they are usually drawn.

name: Bit
description: The smallest unit of digital information. One byte is equal to eight bits.

name: Black Hat
description: The use of questionable tactics to manipulate search engines into pushing poor quality or irrelevant web resources further up the SERP than they deserve to be. The search engines employ sophisticated mathematical formulae to help them remove sites that use these tactics from their listings.

name: Black Hat SEO
description: The use of questionable tactics to manipulate search engines into pushing poor quality or irrelevant web resources further up the SERP than they deserve to be. The search engines employ sophisticated mathematical formulae to help them remove sites that use these tactics from their listings.

name: Blacklist
description: A list of web entities in whose properties an advertiser does not wish their content to be displayed.

name: Bounce Rate
description: Refers to the proportion of users leaving a site immediately, ostensibly without having viewed the content. It should be noted that most analytics tools record bounce rate simply on the basis of those users who have a single interaction with the site, and can thus include users who have spent a great deal of time on a single page before leaving. It is therefore important to consider bounce rate metrics in the context of other data.

name: Brand Advertising
description: A form of advertising whose focus is less on eliciting a response from consumers and more about building long-term positive awareness of the brand amongst consumers. Because brand advertising rarely features a specific call-to-action, it is often more creative and memorable than direct response advertising because the goal is to associate the brand with certain values and behaviours. Brand advertising is usually traded on a CPM basis because clicks are a less useful measure of an ad's effectiveness than attitudes towards the brand, which are harder to measure.

name: Brand Anchor Text
description: Hyperlink anchor text that comprises a brand name or related term. A very high proportion of any natural link profile will contain links with these types of anchor, they are therefore the safest to place in external links to your site.

name: Brand Page
description: Some retailers offer bespoke brand pages that is a page holding all Brand content, across a product range, where further branded information including videos, images and broader category information can be shown

name: Brand response advertising
description: A hybrid of direct response and brand advertising. As in direct response advertising, the goal is to persuade the user to take action, but this action is more about building the long-term health of the brand and capturing user data than securing a sale there and then. The rich, textured interactivity of online ads has made brand response advertising very popular in recent years. Users can now interact with and share ads in quantifiable ways, such as by clicking 'Like' buttons for branded content which is then shared with their friends. The 'cost-per-engagement' metric has emerged as a response to brand response advertising.

name: Browser
description: Software application that enables users to surf the web and input/extract information. It also renders web content in its intended form for users by using a 'layout engine' to translate the HTML into an interactive web page. A web browser can also display non-HTML content such as video, audio, etc. Flash content can be displayed by incorporating Flash plugins into the browser.  The first web browser, WorldWideWeb, was invented by Sir Tim Berners-Lee in 1990. Popular browsers include Apple Safari, Google Chrome, Microsoft Internet Explorer, Mozilla Firefox, and Opera.

name: Bumper
description: Short clips from an advertiser surrounding a sponsored TV show, usually containing the phrase 'sponsored by...'

name: Burst Strategy
description: A burst strategy is a form of media scheduling where media activities are condensed into a series of relatively compact timeframes, usually with relatively long periods of silence in between. Sometimes referred to as 'flighting', burst strategies tend to be 'high-impact' and are often used when launching a new product.

name: Buyral
description: The 'buyral effect' occurs when paid media achieves reach at scale.

name: Byte
description: A unit of digital information equivalent to eight bits. A single text character used to require eight bits, so the byte (sometimes referred to as 'octet') was at one time the smallest useful digital unit.

name: Catalogue and merchandising architecture
description: The structure of the navigation, and therefore the structure of the site, in regards to product categorization and thematic merchandising groupings such as sales, new arrivals and top picks. Brands should work with their retailers to ensure their category is intuitively located as well as the Brand's products across one or more categories

name: Catch-Up TV
description: Video-On-Demand (VOD) services available on connected devices - including televisions - that allow users to watch audiovisual content at a time of their choosing rather than at scheduled broadcast times.

name: Category/Hub Page
description: The page that acts as the entry-point to a category offering for that retailer. It is a space that should aid navigation by providing relevant information to add guidance for shoppers across the main shopping missions

name: CCTLD
description: Country Code Top Level Domain. An identifier used in the Internet Domain Name System (DNS) to identify an internet resource by country. The allocation and management of ccTLDs is overseen by the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA) in the USA. The first ccTLDs, registered in 1985, were .uk (United Kingdom), .us (USA), and .il (Israel). Some smaller companies have been granted permission to licence their ccTLDs for commercial use, e.g. .as (Ascension Island), .be (Belgium) and .ck (Cook Islands).

name: CECs/Carelines
description: Consumer Engagement Centres, otherwise known as CECs or 'Carelines', form one of the three 'pillars' of the PDC. Carelines deliver a twin-pronged approach of providing relationship-building consumer care across multiple touchpoints while also building out richer consumer profiles using surveys and in-call questions.

name: Click through rate
description: Click Through Rate is the percentage of ad impressions in a given campaign that deliver a click. If 1000 ad impressions deliver 10 clicks then the click through rate is 1%. It is expressed mathematically as CTR = (clicks/impressions) x 100.

name: Click Through Rate (CTR)
description: The percentage of shoppers who landed on a certain page/saw a certain aspect of the site that then clicked to progress further. Formula: Clicks / Impressions = Click Through Rate

name: Click-Through Rate (CTR)
description: The proportion of users who actually click through to a particular site as it appears on a SERP.

name: Clickpath analysis
description: Analysis method created to address the problem of 'final click attribution', i.e. when a user clicks multiple ads across multiple sites during a given campaign, but because the final click delivers the sale, only the final site receives the credit and the money. Most ad serving software now offers advanced reporting that provides a more microscopic view of the campaign, enabling you to see where the user viewed and/or clicked before the final action/sale. This information is useful for setting campaign budgets, planning insight data, and rebooking activity. It has several names, but Doubleclick's 'path to conversion analysis' is widely used throughout the industry.

name: Clickstream Data
description: This is essentially the trail of breadcrumbs you leave online: sites visited, pages visited within sites, time spent in each site section, etc. ISPs and network-centric data companies are both able to capture this data.

name: Cloaking
description: The act of hiding content intended for a search engine from the user or vice versa.

name: Commercial Content
description: Content (usually editorial) created for an advertiser by a third party - usually the media owner themselves. The advertiser pays the media owner to generate content on their behalf because the media owner has a proven track record in content generation.

name: Communications Platform
description: An infrastructure composed of physical and virtual assets, which serves to both inspire and facilitate discussion and collaboration between the platform's owner(s) and its users.

name: Compass
description: The digital compass in a mobile phone provides the device with a simple orientation in relation to the Earth's magnetic field. As a result, the phone always knows which way is North so it can auto rotate the screen depending on your physical orientation.

name: Competitor brand bidding
description: The practice of bidding on a competitor's brand terms and trademarks in the AdWords auction. Although the practice has been the subject of several high profile court cases around the world, it is now considered legal as long as the resulting ads do not cause reputational damage to the brand, take advantage of the distinctive character of their trademark by including trademarked terms in the creative, or make it difficult to determine who is selling the advertised product(s). It makes sense to bid on other brand keywords at times because branded keywords have been proven to have much higher click through rates.

name: Conquesting
description: When a competitor brand proactively targets competitor key search terms to appear on the SRP and auto-complete suggestions

name: Consumer Engagement Centre (CEC)
description: Consumer Engagement Centres or 'CECs' form one of the three 'pillars' of the PDC. CECs deliver a twin-pronged approach of providing relationship-building consumer care across multiple touchpoints while also building out richer consumer profiles using surveys and in-call questions.

name: Content Curation
description: The common practice of selecting interesting material from all over the web and presenting it in one place.

name: Content farm
description: A company that employs large numbers of often low paid writers to produce high volume, low quality content designed to rank highly on the search engines' results pages, thereby attracting page views and, by extension, ad revenue. Because the content created is written with the search engines rather than users in mind, it is often unintelligible and littered with repeated keywords. Google's Panda Update was designed to limit the number of content farms in its search results.

name: Content Marketing
description: A strategic approach to marketing involving the creation and distribution of bespoke, engaging content (e.g. video, editorial, apps, etc.) for a defined audience.

name: Contextual targeting
description: An ad technology that enables contextually-relevant ads to be displayed on web pages. Keywords are identified in the web page's content, and advertising is fetched which in theory is appropriate for those keywords. An example of this could be a banner ad for a budget airline appearing around an online article about backpacking in Europe. The members of the 'Google Display Network' have all downloaded a program called AdSense, which is a powerful contextual targeting system.

name: Continuity strategy
description: A continuity strategy is a form of media scheduling where media activities run steadily with little variation over a relatively long period of time. Continuity strategies are often used for existing products, when brands are seeking to reinforce presence in a more continuous way.

name: Conversion
description: This is the percentage of people who take the advertiser's desired action as a result of the ad, whether it be site registration, a sale, etc. If clicks have featured in your user journey the conversion rate can be calculated using the following formula: CR = (number of conversions/number of clicks) x 100.

name: Cookie ID
description: A character string used by websites and servers to identify a unique browser.

name: Copy Text
description: The textual component of a web page or content piece.

name: Copyscape
description: Commercial software that can be used to identify plagiarised content by comparing a sample to other data available on the internet. However, passing a Copyscape check does not guarantee that rewritten content will not be identified as duplicated by search engines.

name: Cost per Acquisition (CPA)
description: Cost per acquisition (or action) is a pricing model where the advertiser pays the online advertiser if an action, such as a sale or a registration, results from a user's exposure to the advertising. It is mostly used by direct response advertisers.

name: Cost Per Click (CPC)
description: Cost per Click is the amount an advertiser pays the online publisher each time a user clicks on their ad. The CPC is affected by several factors, including how much competition there is in the market.

name: Cost Per Mille (CPM)
description: Cost-per-mille (CPM) is the cost of delivering one thousand ad impressions. It can be calculated by dividing the cost of the campaign by the number of thousand impressions delivered.

name: Cost-per-Action (CPA)
description: Cost-per-action (or acquisition) is a pricing model where the advertiser pays the online advertiser if an action, such as a sale or a registration, results from a user's exposure to the advertising. It is mostly used by direct response advertisers.

name: Cost-per-Engagement (CPE)
description: Cost-per-engagement is a relatively new model that has emerged as a response to greater interactivity in online ads and brand response advertising. 'Engagement' is a broad term that encompasses more brand-focused actions such as 'Liking', 'retweeting', etc. It is widely considered to be the brand equivalent of CPA.

name: CPA
description: Cost per Action/Acquisition is a pricing model where the advertiser pays the online advertiser if an action, such as a sale or a registration, results from a user's exposure to the advertising. It is mostly used by direct response advertisers.

name: CPA (Cost Per Action)
description: Cost per Action/Acquisition is a pricing model where the advertiser pays the online advertiser if an action, such as a sale or a registration, results from a user's exposure to the advertising. It is mostly used by direct response advertisers.

name: CPC
description: Cost per Click is the amount an advertiser pays the online publisher each time a user clicks on their ad. The CPC is affected by several factors, including how much competition there is in the market.

name: CPC (Cost Per Click)
description: Cost per Click is the amount an advertiser pays the online publisher each time a user clicks on their ad. The CPC is affected by several factors, including how much competition there is in the market.

name: CPE (Cost Per Engagement)
description: Cost per Engagement is a relatively new model that has emerged as a response to greater interactivity in online ads and brand response advertising. 'Engagement' is a broad term that encompasses more brand-focused actions such as 'Liking', 'retweeting', etc. It is widely considered to be the brand equivalent of CPA.

name: Crawling (Search Engine)
description: When an automated web robot methodically browses the web and processes the content held on each page. Search engines then use this up-to-date data to provide results in response to user queries

name: Creative Commons (CC) License
description: These are a set of prewritten legal templates that can be used to release creative content for free use as long as the new user adheres to the relevant stipulations, limitations or restrictions.

name: Creative tag
description: Link held on the media owner/first party ad server that instructs the user's browser to fetch the ads from the media agency/third party ad server. These tags are provided by the media agency so they can be plugged into the media owner/third party ad server instead of the actual ads.

name: CTR
description: Click Through Rate is the percentage of ad impressions in a given campaign that deliver a click. If 1000 ad impressions deliver 10 clicks then the click through rate is 1%. It is expressed mathematically as CTR = (clicks/impressions) x 100.

name: Data
description: Any information that can be collected on things like consumer profiles, consumer behaviour, campaign and ad performance, etc.

name: Data Points
description: Individual pieces or sources of information or data.

name: Data Processing
description: A wide range of data-related activities are treated as ?processing?, including collecting (obtaining, storing, recording, holding, transferring, receiving), using (altering, organising, sharing) and destroying.

name: Data Protection Officer (DPO)
description: Data Protection Officers or 'DPOs' are designated individuals in Unilever who are responsible for making sure that Unilever follows the new regulations when collecting consumer data and Personally-Identifiable Information (PII).

name: Data Providers
description: Businesses and pieces of technology that aggregate information (data points) by looking at and recording how people behave online.

name: DBT
description: The Digital Briefing Template (DBT) can be used in the planning stages of a campaign (Pre-Market) to set clear objectives for digital assets and align them on KPIs.

name: Deal ID
description: A deal ID, or ‘Deal Identifier’, is a unique number associated with a given ad buy. It is used to match buyers and sellers within the programmatic market according to pre-negotiated criteria.

name: Demand Side Platform (DSP)
description: DSP stands for 'Demand Side Platform': a technology which enables buyers to manage their bids for ad inventory bought via exchanges. In addition, the tracking, optimisation and ad serving capabilities of these platforms enable buyers to make huge efficiencies in terms of cost and return on investment.

name: Digital GRP (Gross Rating Point)
description: An online version of the Gross Rating Point metric found in television advertising. It is expressed as the total online audience reached (as a percentage) times the average frequency.

name: Discrepancy
description: In digital advertising, discrepancy refers to the difference in campaign reporting numbers for key measurements, such as impressions and clicks between multiple adservers. These differences can be caused by a variety of factors including the number of partners involved, the individual user being served the ads, and page load time.

name: Display Advertising
description: A type of multimedia advertising which often uses images (static and moving), sound and text. Banner ads, MPUs/Medium Rectangles and Skyscrapers are typical display ad formats, although formats are continuously evolving. Display ads are very different from classified or search ads, which are typically text-based.

name: DMCA
description: The Digital Millennium Copyright Act is a piece of legislation relevant to the dissemination of copyrighted material on the internet. Among the provisions is one allowing for legal protection for service providers and other internet mediators providing that they act to remove infringing content on receipt of a request from the copyright holder. This means that search engines may be obliged to remove infringing content from SERPS.

name: Dmoz
description: The Open Directory Project (Dmoz) is a Netscape-owned free and open source database of World Wide Web links maintained by volunteer editors around the world. Sites do not have to pay for inclusion.

name: DMP (Data Management Platform)
description: A piece of software that warehouses and analyses audience data for media companies. DMPs are often used to manage Deal IDs and create audience segments for targeting purposes. Data from DMPs is often fed into DSPs to inform buying decisions.

name: Domain
description: Officially an identifier that defines any complete internet resource, it is more commonly defined as an identifier for an entire website rather than any of the resources found within it, e.g. web pages.

name: Doorway page
description: A page that often has little to no relation to the search term for which it is found whose function is simply to redirect the user to another site. It looks and feels right to the search engines because the right keywords and meta description have been used, but the page itself is simply a facade designed to lead the user elsewhere. This is a standard 'black hat' SEO technique.

name: DSP
description: DSP stands for 'Demand Side Platform': a technology which enables buyers to manage their bids for ad inventory bought via exchanges. In addition, the tracking, optimisation and ad serving capabilities of these platforms enable buyers to make huge efficiencies in terms of cost and return on investment.

name: DSP (Demand Side Platform)
description: A technology which enables buyers to manage their bids for ad inventory bought via exchanges. In addition, the tracking, optimisation and ad serving capabilities of these platforms enable buyers to make huge efficiencies in terms of cost and return on investment.

name: E-Commerce
description: Online commerce e.g. online retailers, online sales, etc.

name: Earned Media
description: Earned media are media that are passed between consumers as a result of a direct experience with a brand, e.g. a retweet, a Facebook 'Like', a Pinterest 'Pin It', a FourSquare 'Check In', a positive review in an influential blog, etc. ?

name: eCommerce
description: Online commerce e.g. online retailers, online sales, etc.

name: Email
description: Electronic Mail. Invented in the 1960s for exchanging messages on the same computer, it was not until Ray Tomlinson sent the first network email to computers positioned side-by-side (and used the '@' sign for this purpose for the first time) that email's potential began to be realised. Soon, it was routinely used across ARPAnet, the U.S. military precursor to the Internet. Email clients like Microsoft Outlook and Mozilla Thunderbird do not strictly require the Web to operate because pure email uses Internet protocols other than HTTP (POP3 and IMAP in the main), but web-based email ('webmail') clients such as GMail and Hotmail are now more popular than their desktop counterparts.

name: Exact match
description: The most precise matching option offered in Google's AdWords. An ad may be displayed only if its exact keyword or phrase is searched for, with no other terms included in the search query. Misspellings, acronyms, abbreviations, accents, stemmings, and singular and plural forms of the keyword(s) are included in the matching option, so the ad may be displayed for these as well.

name: Exact Match Anchor Text
description: Hyperlink anchor text containing keywords that have specific value for SEO. This is often done deliberately in an attempt to increase the relevance of the linked site for a search term. However, exploiting external anchor text for SEO purposes is very easy to detect by looking at an entire link profile and thus has a high chance of attracting penalties from search engines.

name: Feature phone
description: These are standard mobile phones with limited smartphone functionality. Like smartphones, they can possess GPS navigation, touchscreens, cameras and Wi-Fi capability. However, third-party apps cannot utilise these phones' core functions to the same extent that smartphone apps can.

name: Feed-Based Video
description: Video content that appears within the news feed on social media platforms.

name: Filter
description: A feature that enables shoppers to refine a product list page by pre-set tags. Filters should be category specific e.g. Brand, Format, Size

name: First party ad server
description: Alternate name for the media owner ad server. This server holds creative tags from the media agency. These tags instruct the user's browser to fetch the actual ads from the media agency/third party ad server.

name: First Party Data
description: Audience data wholly owned and collected by a media company, e.g. Mail Online.

name: Flash
description: Software framework that enables users to create animation, games and rich media content. Flash's SWF and FLV file formats quickly displaced GIF as the file formats of preference for web developers. However, HTML5 poses an existential threat to the platform because unlike Flash HTML5 is web-native and does not require plugins to function on web pages. The name 'Flash' originates from Macromedia's purchase of FutureSplash, the second version of the framework, in 1996. Macromedia combined 'Future' and 'Splash' to make 'Flash', a title the platform retained when Macromedia was purchased by Adobe Systems in 2005.

name: Floor Price
description: A minimum bid a seller is willing to accept for ad inventory within an auction. Some sellers may set lower floor prices as a way of capturing buyer data, but in the main floor prices are designed to prevent inventory from becoming unprofitable.

name: FMCGs
description: Fast Moving Consumer Goods (FMCGs) are retail items such as foodstuffs, toiletries, cleaning products and low end consumer electronics that are intended to be sold and replaced very quickly. The profit margins for the manufacturers are small, but FMCGs sell in such large quantities that profits overall are extremely high. FMCGs are contrasted with other goods such as 'durable goods' (e.g. cars, computers, mobile phones, etc.) and 'major appliances' (e.g. washing machines, fridges, dishwashers, etc.).

name: Frequency Capping
description: This is the practice of capping the number of times an ad is shown to a particular user, to prevent possible oversaturation and annoyance.

name: FTP
description: File Transfer Protocol. A widely used network protocol, invented in 1971 by Internet pioneer Abhay Bhushan, that allows computers (AKA "hosts") to exchange files over a network.  This network is usually, but not always, the internet.

name: Full Stack
description: A company that encompasses all, or a large number of, the different ad tech capabilities under one roof e.g. ad servers, DSPs, SSPs, DMPs, analytics tools, etc.

name: Geo-fencing
description: Uses GPS technology to establish virtual boundaries around defined areas, such as tourist destinations, shops, and workplaces. When a mobile device such as a smartphone enters or exits a geo-fence, a notification is sent to the device. This system can be used by marketers to target consumers based on location.

name: GIF
description: GIF is an acronym for Graphics Interchange Format. This is an image format launched by CompuServe in 1987 that used to be the de facto format for image presentation on the World Wide Web. Its colour palette for a single frame is limited to 256, making it unsuitable for presenting high definition images such as photographs. However, before it was superseded by the Shockwave Flash (swf) and Flash Video (flv) file formats, it was used for all static and dynamic web images, including those incorporated into early web advertisements. The format is now principally used for presenting sharp-edged images with limited colour palettes.

name: Gigabyte
description: 1024 megabytes

name: Gold Campaign
description: Gold campaigns are those where incremental contribution to turnover is greater than 0.5%. Gold campaigns run for at least 9 months and as such, will normally involve significant activity such as a major innovation or a new brand or category launch.

name: Google Custom Search
description: AdSense feature which enables site owners to place custom Google search engines on their sites. These can either act as general search tools or only include results from pages within the domains.

name: Google Display Network
description: Network of websites that use the Google AdSense program to host contextually targeted ads from Google in their page real estate. They can also incorporate custom Google search bars into their sites using AdSense. Google splits the revenue from any clicks with the site.

name: Google Tag Manager
description: Is a software system that helps web masters manage and consolidate tracking tags and code, such as cookies, on a specific web page. This can greatly simplify the technical implementation of an analytics strategy.

name: Google Webmaster Tools
description: Google’s toolkit for webmasters. When implemented on a site, webmaster tools provides webmasters with a broad range of features, including but not limited to: site map submission, error messages and warnings, sample links and traffic data. We recommend webmaster tool implementation for all websites.

name: Googlebot
description: Google's proprietary web crawler used for indexing web content.

name: GRP (Gross Rating Point)
description: A broadcast TV measure of ad exposure expressed as the total audience reached (as a percentage) times average frequency. One rating point is usually equal to one per cent of the target audience.

name: GTLD
description: Generic Top Level Domain.  An identifier usually found at the end of addresses used in the Internet Domain Name System (DNS) to identify an internet resource by function. The connection between a specific function and a gTLD has been abandoned in some cases, e.g. .com (commercial), .net (networking technology) and .org (non-profit organisation). However, the descriptive association has been maintained for other resources, e.g. .gov (government), .edu (U.S. educational establishments), and .mobi (mobile sites).

name: Gyroscope
description: A sensor in a mobile device which measures the orientation of the device. It can sense motion, tracking rotation or twist and measuring the angular rotational velocity. A gyroscope can provide precision motion inside app functionality, and a user can execute the majority of the tasks with the motion of the device only.

name: H1 Tag
description: The most prominent heading tag available within HTML. This should only be used once on each page, usually to form the main heading. The H1 tag is an important location with regard to keyword placement. The default H1 appearance can be altered by adding additional styling code to the tag.

name: Holding Company
description: A company whose purpose is to own (usually controlling) shares in other companies.

name: Home Page
description: The default page that loads when a shopper first lands on the retailer’s site. It is equivalent to both the shop window and the front of store in physical store terms

name: Hotlinking
description: The act of linking to a piece of content in such a way that it is displayed on one location but still hosted and served from another. This is poor internet etiquette in most cases as this places the cost of serving the content on the source site. However, from an SEO perspective you are usually better off having another user hotlink to your content rather than re-host it on their own. You should not hotlink to images on other sites however, because a hotlinked image can be swapped for any other, at any time, by the hosting server.

name: HTML
description: HyperText Markup Language. The language created in 1990 by Sir Tim Berners-Lee that enables browsers to render web resources in their intended formats and display them to users. Plain text is enclosed and "marked up" in a series of instructional, bracketed tags whose purpose is to inform the browser where and in what size and with what function (e.g. a hyperlink) that text should be displayed to the user. However, the look and feel of web pages composed in HTML is also shaped by the Cascading Style Sheet (CSS) language. HTML used to be incapable of describing rich media objects such as Flash content, but its latest iteration, HTML5, can now instruct browsers to render rich media content as well.

name: HTML5
description: HyperText Markup Language 5. This is the fifth version of HTML, the markup language that instructs web browsers how to present information on a web page. Unlike previous versions, HTML5 no longer requires plugins like Flash to display multimedia content.

name: HTTP
description: HyperText Transfer Protocol. The communications standard/application protocol for the World Wide Web invented by Sir Tim Berners-Lee. Documents on the World Wide Web composed in HyperText Markup Language (HTML) link to each other via hypertext. HTTP is the protocol that enables the exchange and transfer of hypertext. Both the term 'hypertext' and the concept itself actually predate the World Wide Web. Sociologist and IT philosopher Ted Nelson devised hypertext as an abstract system in 1963, inspired, he claims, by the need to track his own thought processes.

name: Hummingbird Update
description: An update to the Google PageRank algorithm whose first iteration was released in August 2013. It is a core algorithm update whose impact is comparable to that of the Caffeine Index update of 2010. This is not a security/spamdexing related update; instead, it is the algorithm change behind semantic search and the Knowledge Graph.

name: Hyperlink
description: A website element that allows users to navigate directly to another website or piece of web content.

name: IAB
description: The Internet Advertising Bureau UK (IAB) is the trade association for online and mobile advertisers.

name: iBeacon
description: iBeacon is Apple's indoor positioning system, which enables iPhone users to receive notifications and make instore payments via Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) wireless personal area network technology.

name: Identifer For Advertisers (IDFA)
description: Apple's IDFA replaces the defunct UDID (Unique Device Identifier) system, which raised user privacy concerns. It is a random serial number assigned to iOS devices on a temporary basis (unlike the UDID).  This number is used by ad servers to target iOS user segments (rather than individual users) by browsing and/or search activity and deliver relevant ads to them.

name: Image Gallery
description: A catalogue of SKU images held on the PDP

name: Implied Consent
description: Implied consent is an assumption of permission to do something that is inferred from an individual's actions rather than explicitly provided. An example is when a consumer calls a consumer helpline to ask a question about a brand's product (e.g. allergens). The brand would need their contact details to respond to the query. By giving their details, this implies that the consumer is happy for the brand to store them and use them to respond.

name: In-Banner Video
description: Video content that appears within a traditional digital display banner on a webpage.

name: In-stream advertising
description: In stream advertising refers to ad spaces that are not separate to the content but lie within the body (or the ‘stream’) of the editorial.

name: Internet Domain
description: Officially, an Internet domain is an identifier that defines any complete Internet resource. However, it is more commonly defined as an identifier for an entire website rather than any of the resources found within it, e.g. web pages.

name: Internet of Things (IoT)
description: A development of the existing computer-based internet paradigm in which thousands of previously inert objects will be internet-enabled. Phones and watches are merely the first wave of this phenomenon. Household goods (e.g. refrigerators), automobiles, farming and medical equipment are all beginning to include internet connectivity, turning them into de facto “smart devices”. As the internet extends beyond the computing paradigm and into everyday life, rich data capture is expected to increase by  an order of magnitude.

name: Inventory
description: The amount of advertising space available at any given supply-side source.

name: IP Address
description: A number assigned by an Internet Service Provider (ISP) to any device (e.g. mobile, desktop computer, internet television, etc.) on the Internet. These numbers are in turn assigned to ISPs by the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA) in the USA. They are used for the purposes of identifying and locating networked devices. Each IP address can be expressed decimally for human eyes, e.g. 91.106.249.139, but they are binary numbers in reality, meaning they are composed entirely of the numbers '0' and '1'.  There are two IP address systems currently in use: IPv4 and IPv6. IPv4 is currently undergoing a process of deprecation to encourage uptake of the newer IPv6 system, which makes many more IP addresses available.

name: IP Block
description: IP addresses that share a numerical relationship are often assigned to the same distributor (such as an internet hosting company) and issued to clients at the same time. An IP address can be divided up into blocks as follows: AAA.BBB.CCC.DDD. Multiple links from addresses with the same C block, that is those which are identical apart from the last 3 numbers, can indicate that the links have originated from closely-related sites, such as an SEO link network.

name: ISP
description: Internet Service Provider. Businesses that provide internet access, e.g. Virgin, BT, Sky, Verizon, etc. The first commercial ISP to grant Internet access to the general public (rather than academics and military personnel) was 'The World' in November 1989, one year prior to the creation of the World Wide Web.

name: JavaScript
description: A programming language, often used to create interactive web content. Because of the relatively unrestricted nature of such coding, JavaScript-created content is incredibly hard for search crawlers to parse, and such content will therefore generally not contribute to a search engine’s determination of ranking.

name: JavaScript tags
description: An advanced form of tracking/action tag. As with the basic tracking/action tag, a 1x1 pixel (and a separate cookie) is delivered to isolate and identify an action such as a sale, but the use of the JavaScript computer programming language allows the ad server to capture much richer data. Instead of just sale confirmation coming through, the ad server can break sales down into numbers of products sold, average value of products, etc. However, the cost of capturing this richer data is sometimes a noticeable increase in the loading time of the web page. This can have an adverse effect on both Google and Bing search rankings and customer activity on e-commerce sites.

name: Key Performance Indicator (KPI)
description: A chosen measure of performance for a given business undertaking (e.g. a campaign).

name: Keyword
description: In the context of SEO a keyword is a word, or sequence of words, that is of particular relevance to the specific website or page. Often corresponding to search terms which could be expected to bring traffic.

name: Keyword Planner
description: AdWords tool which enables you to research the keywords you want to use, look at their historical performance and then estimate how they might perform for your campaign in the short to medium term.

name: Keyword Stuffing
description: The act of attempting to maximise keyword usage at the expense of usability. This is no longer an effective SEO technique and should no longer be engaged in.

name: Keywords
description: In the context of SEO a keyword is a word, or sequence of words, that is of particular relevance to the specific website or page. Often corresponding to search terms which could be expected to bring traffic.

name: Kilobyte
description: 1024 bytes

name: Knowledge Graph
description: Google's first foray into semantic search, which takes the form of a display embedded in the SERP providing supplementary information on a given search topic. The Knowledge Graph moves beyond keywords to provide more holistic and relevant search results through structured "ontologies".

name: KPI
description: KPI is an acronym for Key Performance Indicator, and is a measure of performance for a given business undertaking (e.g. a campaign).

name: Landing Page
description: The first page arrived at by those visiting a site ? often but not always the homepage. For organic search traffic, this will be whichever page was linked to on the SERP. In SEO it?s important to be aware of landing pages, and work towards providing appropriate landing pages for different categories of incoming users.

name: Last Click Model
description: A type of campaign analytics or modelling that attributes all the success of the campaign to the ad that received the final click before the desired action (e.g. purchase) was taken.

name: Linear TV
description: Television viewed at the scheduled time of broadcast on its intended channel. VOD and catch-up TV services are rapidly undermining this format, but it is still the main way TV is consumed.

name: Link bait
description: A small piece of content, e.g. a useful or entertaining infographic, video or application designed to direct users back to your main site. This is a key weapon in the off-site SEO practitioner's arsenal.

name: Link Building
description: The act of placing links pointing back to a website solely for the SEO value that they might provide.

name: List Page
description: A page that shows a number of SKUs in response to a shopper’s navigation. These pages can often be sorted by price, rating or other category common metrics

name: Local Loop Unbundling
description: A legislative process, beginning with a report by the European Commission in 1993, that culminated in governments worldwide ordering companies with telecommunications infrastructure monopolies (referred to as Incumbent Local Exchange Carriers, or 'ILECs', in the USA) to make their infrastructure up to competitors. This allowed companies that did not own physical telecommunications infrastructure (e.g. cables and exchanges) to offer internet access to consumers. Most unbundling in the major Western economies took place in 1996.

name: Lost Impressions
description: The discrepancy in impression count that can occur between two different ad tech providers due to different measurement technologies, for example.

name: Malware
description: Malicious software. This can have a wide variety of adverse effects when introduced to a computer system, including, but not limited to: stealing personal data; recording user activity; hijacking system resources for criminal activity and even compromising security systems to further increase vulnerability to additional malware.

name: Mashups
description: Also known as ‘Web Application Hybrids’, Mashups take data and services from different websites and integrate them into a single application. When large applications released their APIs, it became possible for developers to take data from two or more sources and create a ‘mashup’ in which data from one was combined with data from the other(s) to create an application with an esoteric function.

name: Media buyer
description: An individual who works to purchase advertising time (in the case of television and radio) and space/placement (in the case of press and digital) for their clients' ads.

name: Media Channel
description: A specific vehicle for transmitting messages, e.g. radio, television, newsletters, magazines, mobile, social networking service, etc. Digital is not a media channel because it simply refers to the way the information transmitted by internet-enabled devices is packaged, sent and received. Instead, digital is best defined as a 'transmission method'.

name: Media Neutral Planning
description: A planning approach that resembles transmedia planning inasmuch as several media channels are considered from the outset, only the message itself is static and "media neutral", i.e. it does not change from channel to channel. In other words, the media's influence over the message is minimal.

name: Megabyte
description: 1024 kilobytes

name: Meta description
description: An HTML label containing a short description of a page's content of no more than 156 words. This description appears on the SERP as the 'snippet' beneath the page title. If no meta description can be found, the search engines will look elsewhere for the snippet.

name: Micro Conversions
description: Micro conversions are viewed as a bit of a digital buzzword and we don’t really have a working definition for them at this point. As a result, many brands only have a limited understanding of what they are and how they should be measured. Most advertisers take a micro-conversion to mean any value-added action taken by a user that sits outside of the brand or product’s primary KPI (Key Performance Indicator), e.g. app downloads, social media likes, newsletter sign ups etc.

name: Micropayment
description: An e-commerce transaction, usually involving a relatively small amount of money, through which an online product such as a movie, song or game can be purchased (or rented) online. Charitable donations can also be made through micropayment systems. Apple uses an aggregated micropayment system on its iTunes application.

name: Mid-Roll Ad
description: Ads that play during other video content. Traditional TV commercial breaks are an example of mid-roll advertising.

name: MMM
description: Marketing Mix Modelling, or 'MMM', is a tool for determining ROI of media spend. It's available globally through CMI Analytics for campaigns that have run for at least 6 weeks.

name: MMS
description: MultiMedia Messaging Service. Although it has nothing in common with SMS technologically, it was designed to complement SMS by enabling pictures, videos and audio to be exchanged between mobile phones.

name: Mobile Operator
description: These are the companies who own and maintain the networks used by mobile phone users. Examples include Orange, Vodafone, AT&T, T-Mobile, O2 and 3.

name: Mobile OS
description: Mobile Operating System. These are similar to operating systems like Windows or Linux on your home computer, but they are specific to mobile devices such as smartphones and tablets. As such, they also have to control additional functions such as touchscreen capability, speech recognition, GPS navigation and camera capability. The most common mobile operating systems - all of which have gone through several named and/or numbered iterations - are Apple's 'iOS' and Google's 'Android'.

name: MPU
description: MPU stands for Multi-Purpose Unit - one of the standard online ad formats, at 300x250 pixels.

name: Negative match
description: Prevents an ad from being displayed if certain keywords are present in the search query. Below the AdWords keyword matching table is a smaller table reserved for defining negative match keywords, all of which must be prefixed with a minus sign. This is a useful option for screening out irrelevant search terms that are unlikely to lead to a click.

name: Negative SEO
description: Black Hat SEO techniques that are intended to actively damage the rankings of rival websites, usually by faking exploitative SEO activity on behalf of the target in order to trigger a search penalty.

name: Network Carrier/Operator/Provider
description: These are the companies who own and maintain the networks used by mobile phone users. Examples include Orange, Vodafone, AT&T, T-Mobile, O2 and 3.

name: Network-Centric Data
description: This approach involves the use of proprietary software to intercept the website logs held by Internet Service Providers (ISPs) such as Sky and BT to analyse site usage data. Because this data is anonymous it is often combined with data from panels so audiences can be profiled in demographic groups. Sample sizes can often be in the millions, so network-centric data companies such as Hitwise and Quantcast often have very detailed information on search traffic.

name: News Feed Video
description: Video content that appears within the news feed on social media platforms.

name: NFC
description: Near Field Communication. This technology allows mobile devices to establish radio contact with each other over short distances or by direct contact. The new field of mobile retailing is heavily-reliant on NFC technology.

name: Nofollow
description: ‘Nofollow’ is a value that can be assigned to the ‘rel’ attribute of an HTML element. It instructs search engines that the hyperlink should not influence the ranking of the link's target in the search engine's index. It can also be used in the content of a robot’s ‘meta tag’ to instruct search engines not to follow links from the page.

name: Non-Skippable Ad
description: A video ad of up to 30 seconds in length which does not offer the option to skip.

name: O&O (Owned & Operated Content)
description: A term originally used to refer to local TV and radio stations owned and operated by major broadcast networks. 'Owned and Operated' now also refers to content created by the brand and distributed through owned web and social media properties such as Facebook pages.

name: OEM
description: Original Equipment Manufacturer. These are mobile device manufacturers who buy software or components from other companies for use in their own products. For instance, Samsung mobile devices use Google's Android operating system.

name: Online publisher
description: Any individual or organisation that publishes online content on an owned platform such as a website or a blog. This content does not have to be textual, so Channel 4 and Mail Online are both regarded as online publishers despite their very different content offerings. Because social media sites like Facebook and Twitter do not publish content of their own they are not regarded as online publishers.

name: Organic Search
description: The listings that appear on the SERP as a natural result of search algorithm discovery. This is in contrast to the 'paid listings' where advertisers pay to appear beside and above the natural listings through ad products such as Google AdWords.

name: Organic Search Results
description: The Search Results Page showing the results (could be products, images or websites) that are deemed most relevant to the search term entered

name: Owned and Operated (O&O)
description: A term originally used to refer to local TV and radio stations owned and operated by major broadcast networks. 'Owned and Operated' now also refers to content created by the brand and distributed through owned web and social media properties such as Facebook pages.

name: Owned Media
description: Owned media are media that are now created and owned by the marketer and or the brand, i.e. YouTube channel, website, microsite, Facebook page, brand media assets, etc.

name: Page impression/page view
description: A request, received by a web server, to view one page of a website.

name: Page Rank
description: The search algorithm at the heart of the Google search engine named after its co-author, Larry Page. Inspired by the academic peer review/citation system, it uses the strength, quality and number of links to web resources as a measure of their relevance to any search query. The algorithm is constantly updated in order to combat strategies designed to trick it into assigning a higher PageRank to websites than they deserve. Its importance has been downplayed in recent years due to successive algorithm updates, but the argument could be made that PageRank is still the backbone of the Google search algorithm.

name: Page Titles
description: Tag that serves as the title of the page for both the search engines and the user. It appears in the browser's 'chrome' (the page title at the top of the browser) and in all appropriate tabs. Most importantly, it is the title of the page above the snippet on the SERP. The maximum displayable size of this title is determined by pixel width, equivalent to roughly 69 characters for title tags.

name: Paid Media
description: Paid media is where the brand or their representatives pay to leverage a channel not controlled or owned by the brand. This might involve buying ads or advertorials from companies who own media channels a brand wants to reach, such as Sky, Google, The New York Times, Twitter, Facebook, etc.

name: Panda
description: An update to the Google PageRank algorithm whose first iteration was released in February 2011. New ranking criteria were introduced in order to prevent low quality content such as that produced by content farms from ranking highly on the SERP. These criteria were established by a number of users who were asked to rank sites in terms of quality. The high quality sites they selected were then compared and contrasted using sophisticated artificial intelligence to find common traits which were then incorporated into the algorithm's search criteria.

name: Path to Conversion Analysis/Multiple Source Attribution
description: Analysis method created to address the problem of 'final click attribution', i.e. when a user clicks multiple ads across multiple sites during a given campaign, but because the final click delivers the sale, only the final site receives the credit and the money. Most ad serving software now offers advanced reporting that provides a more microscopic view of the campaign, enabling you to see where the user viewed and/or clicked before the final action/sale. This information is useful for setting campaign budgets, planning insight data, and rebooking activity. It has several names, but Doubleclick's 'path to conversion analysis' is widely used throughout the industry.

name: Pay-To-Watch
description: A funding model in which viewers make a one-off payment to watch a particular piece of content. Broadcast television channels pioneered the model for sporting events in the 1980s, but it is now the default method of content delivery for many online services, such as iTunes, Google Play and Amazon Instant Video.

name: Paywall
description: Mainly employed by news organisations and academic publishers, paywalls are systems put in place to restrict access to web content to users who have not paid a subscription or a one-off payment. As publishers make the transition from print to digital editions of their publications, advertising revenue can sometimes be insufficient to cover the costs of creating an online edition. Paywalls can supplement (or even replace) advertising revenue if demand for an online edition is high enough. The online edition of the Financial Times is a model of how to make a paywall system financially viable.

name: Penguin
description: An update to the Google PageRank algorithm whose first iteration was released in April 2012. Unlike the Panda Update, its official purpose is to penalize sites which employ 'black hat' SEO techniques to appear unnaturally high on the SERP. The update searches for tell-tale signs of black hat techniques such as cloaking, keyword stuffing, link bombing, etc.

name: Penguin Update
description: An update to the Google PageRank algorithm whose first iteration was released in April 2012. Unlike the Panda Update, its official purpose is to penalise sites which employ 'black hat' SEO techniques to appear unnaturally high on the SERP. The update searches for tell-tale signs of black hat techniques such as cloaking, keyword stuffing, link bombing, etc.

name: People Relationship Marketing (PRM)
description: People Relationship Marketing is one of the three 'pillars' of the PDC. It is both Unilever?s consumer data storage facility and its capability to create owned audiences for brands.

name: Personally-Identifiable Information (PII)
description: Personally-Identifiable information (PII) refers to information which can be used to directly or indirectly identify an individual. This could be information such as a name, date of birth, phone number, or email address, but also demographic or behavioural data.

name: Phablet
description: A hybrid mobile device providing an intermediate size between a smartphone and a tablet, typically with a screen size between 5 and 6 inches. Phablets are designed to combine the capabilities of both smartphones and tablets, offering portability and functionality crossed with a more dynamic, big-screen experience.

name: Phrase match
description: Broadens the keyword matching possibilities by grouping terms together to form phrases. Surrounding phrases with quotation marks in the AdWords keyword table allows ads to be triggered for exact phrases in the correct order, as well as for any close variants such as misspellings, acronyms, singular and plural forms, accents, and abbreviations.

name: Post click tracking
description: A tracking method used to account for the large number of users who see an ad and click on it to visit the advertiser's site, but perform the desired action (usually a sale) some days or even weeks later.  With this method, two cookies are used: a 'click cookie' and a 'tracking/action cookie'. The click cookie is dropped when the user clicks on the ad and visits the advertiser's site. It then remains on the user's computer for a maximum of thirty days, during which a tracking/action cookie will be dropped on them if they return to the site and proceed to the thank you page. This thirty day window is intended to give the marketer a sense of whether or not it was the advertising that led to the user taking the desired action. The combination of the two cookies identifies the user as someone who both saw the ad and carried out the action.

name: Post impression tracking
description: A tracking method used to account for users who perform a desired action as a result of seeing an ad, but who do not click on the ad itself. It works by dropping a 'seen cookie' on users who have seen the ad on the media owner site but failed to click. This seen cookie remains on the user's computer for far less time than the 'click cookie' used in post-click tracking; one or two days at the most. If the user completes the action, a tracking cookie is dropped on their computer. The combination of the seen cookie and the tracking cookie attributes the sale to the ad and identifies the user.

name: Post-Roll Ad
description: Ads that are played after other video content.

name: PPC/Paid Search
description: PPC (‘Pay Per Click’) or ‘Paid Search’ is the search engine marketing counterpart to SEO (Search Engine Optimisation). Paid Search involves paying for exposure on a SERP rather than ‘winning’ the exposure organically, and your paid link will usually appear alongside the organic listings - but clearly labelled as a paid ad. You will usually be charged a fee every time a user clicks on your paid ad, in agreement with a price that has already been negotiated with the search engine. For a full introduction to this important digital channel, please check out one of our lessons on this topic.

name: Pre-Roll Ad
description: A TV-style video ad intended to be viewed before online video content. Mid and post-roll ads also exist, but pre-rolls are currently thought to be the most impactful because they precede content, which is when anticipation is highest.

name: Primary Navigation Bar
description: Main navigation structure found at the top of the retailer’s home page (above the fold) and often static across all pages. It’s the site navigation that welcomes shoppers and provides a quick high-level view of retailer’s offering

name: Privacy Impact Assessment (PIA)
description: The Privacy Impact Assessment (PIA) is a decision tool used to identify and minimise any potential privacy risks before collecting consumer data.

name: Privacy Notice
description: A privacy notice, sometimes known as a privacy statement or privacy policy, is a statement or a legal document that provides individuals with information on how their personal data is processed i.e. how it is collected, used, stored, deleted and managed.

name: Private Marketplace
description: A 'closed auction' within programmatic trading, which allows the publisher tigher control over which kinds of buyers, advertisers and ads are displayed on their sites; and allows advertisers more control over where their ads will be shown, usually resulting in higher CPMs and higher yields.

name: Programmatic Ads
description: The automation of the buying and selling of display advertising using real-time-bidding. Large retailers are starting to operate their own media platforms enabling brands to buy advertising space for co-location, cross-selling and conquesting opportunities

name: Prospecting display
description: Prospecting' display advertising is advertising geared at acquiring new customers - in particular ones who may not yet have expressed an interest in the product advertised. Prospecting activity concerns channels towards the top of the marketing funnel, and carries a high CPA (Cost Per Acquisition) value due to the difficulty of conversion. However, that does not mean it should be disregarded because the value of acquiring new customers can be huge in the long term.

name: PSO
description: Perfect Store Online, or ‘PSO’, is a dashboard showing the compliance of retailer websites to 7 Omnichannel Assets. It ensures that products are best presented for visibility and availability, identifying necessary updates to product information pages where required.

name: PTD (Publisher Trading Desk)
description: See 'Trading Desk'.

name: Pulse strategy
description: Pulsing is a form of media scheduling where media activities are scheduled at relatively regular intervals, with periodic increases to boost impact during key time periods. Pulsing combines elements of both Burst and Continuous strategies.

name: Purchase intent
description: The likelihood that a consumer will purchase an advertised product in the near future.

name: Pure Play Social Networks
description: Originally used in stock trading to refer to a publicly traded company with a single business focus, pure play in the digital space refers to either an online vendor with no physical stores or a service with a single proposition.  Pure play social sites fall into the latter category because networking is their lone focus. Multichannel services with networking elements do not fall into the pure play category because they operate in several segments.↵↵While the big three players in social networking (Facebook, LinkedIn & Twitter) have successfully shored up their strong positions in the social space, they have been forced to diversify because other sites are beginning to incorporate deep social features. Social plugins, deep integration and frictionless sharing all represent attempts to monetise social networking sites by turning them into de facto multichannel services without compromising their pure play appeal.

name: QR code
description: Quick Response Code. This is a form of barcode that allows for the storage of greater amounts of information than traditional barcodes. The distribution pattern of the small squares adds another layer of information to the standard line width of a normal barcode. Originally developed for the car industry, they have become popular with smartphone users because a QR code reader app can use the phone's camera to translate large amounts of data. Redirection to a URL is the most common application of this technology.

name: Qualitative Data
description: Descriptive rather than numerical/statistical data. Information regarding consumers’ personal attributes, habits and preferences are all examples of qualitative data.

name: Real-Time Bidding (RTB)
description: The buying and selling of ad impressions on an individual basis in “real time” through an automated auction. The winning ad is then served instantaneously to the user whenever they visit the media owner website.

name: Rel Attribute
description: A ‘rel’ attribute is the part of the HTML code for a hyperlink that can be used to describe the relationship between the linked web content and the linking location. One example of a rel attribute is ‘nofollow’.

name: Render
description: Abbreviation of “rendered image” and for online it refers to product images that contain only the essential elements the Brand want to communicate e.g. removal of barcode to better see branding

name: Repertoire
description: A repertoire is a set of brands that individual consumers consider for their purchase of a product within a given category.

name: Resolution
description: The clarity of an image resulting in the number of pixels in the image- the higher the number of pixels the image has, the better and clearer the image will be. High quality images play an important part in providing shoppers with all of the necessary information to make a buying decision especially as they cannot physically hold the product

name: Responsive Design
description: A type of website design based on a fluid layout that will automatically resize depending on browser and device being used by the shopper giving an optimized visual. Responsive design can accommodate considerable structural changes to adapt to habits of mobile phone surfers (e.g. hidden menus or touch screen attributes)

name: Retargeting
description: The practice of using various tracking technologies to deliver ads to users whose online activity already indicates an interest in the product or service advertised. This activity does not necessarily involve a commercial transaction.

name: Return on Ad Spend (ROAS)
description: ROAS stands for 'Return On Ad Spend' and is a helpful metric used in digital acquisition marketing. Compared to CPA (Cost Per Acquisition), ROAS gives a more robust understanding of how media is performing, as it is linked to wider business concerns. ROAS can be calculated with the equation: revenue minus ad spend. However, ROAS calculations ignore the operational costs inherent in running any business, so is often considered alongside other metrics such as ROI (Return On Investment).

name: Return on Investment (ROI)
description: Return on Investment. A common performance metric, expressed as either a ratio or a percentage, which is calculated by dividing the gain from an investment by the cost of the investment. The formula is as follows: ROI = (Gain from Investment - Cost of Investment)/Cost of Investment

name: Rich content (A+ content)
description: Enhanced and extended product page content that provides shoppers with information above and beyond product descriptions. It will include detailed product description, maximum number of images including video content, comparison charts across the portfolio and any other engaging content to optimise the shopper experience. Known as A+ content for Amazon

name: Rich Media
description: Rich Media is a digital advertising term for ads that incorporate advanced features like video, audio or other elements which encourage viewers to interact and engage with the content. While text ads sell with words, and display ads sell with pictures, Rich Media ads offer more advanced ways to enhance an audience’s experience of an ad and stimulate a response.

name: ROAS
description: ROAS stands for 'Return On Ad Spend' and is a helpful metric used in digital acquisition marketing. Compared to CPA (Cost Per Acquisition), ROAS gives a more robust understanding of how media is performing, as it is linked to wider business concerns. ROAS can be calculated with the equation: revenue minus ad spend. However, ROAS calculations ignore the operational costs inherent in running any business, so is often considered alongside other metrics such as ROI (Return On Investment).

name: ROI
description: Return on Investment. A common performance metric, expressed as either a ratio or a percentage, which is calculated by dividing the gain from an investment by the cost of the investment. The formula is as follows:  ROI = (Gain from Investment - Cost of Investment)/Cost of Investment

name: RSS
description: Really Simple Syndication. This is a system by which regularly-updated content can be delivered to the user without the need for multiple visits to web pages or blogs. Using an RSS reader or aggregator, content from sites of interest is delivered directly to the user, creating a more personalised browsing experience. Content updates in real time, giving the user a dynamic web experience tailored to and by them. Some websites such as Google News, Drudge Report and The Huffington Post use the same system, collecting news articles culled from all over the web in one place. These and other similar sites are known as News Aggregators.

name: RTB (Real Time Bidding)
description: The buying and selling of ad impressions on an individual basis in “real time” through an automated auction. The winning ad is then served instantaneously to the user whenever they visit the media owner website.

name: Salience
description: Salience describes the ability for a brand to stand out in a consumer’s mind in a buying situation.

name: Sandbox
description: Also known as “application containerisation”, sandboxing refers to the practice of preventing application code from executing in certain environments. In other words, the app is walled off from other apps on the device in order to prevent data security issues or infection. The term derives from children’s sandboxes, which are walled off areas of playgrounds filled with sand for leisure and child safety purposes.

name: Search Crawler
