description: An automated computer program whose function is to scour the World Wide Web for content, and then categorise it for indexing by a search engine.

name: Search Engine Marketing (SEM)
description: Sometimes used to refer just to paid search activity, SEM or Search Engine Marketing is most properly used as an umbrella term to cover all aspects of both organic and paid search marketing.

name: Search Engine Optimisation (SEO)
description: SEO stands for 'Search Engine Optimisation', and is the practice of optimizing a website using various different techniques in order to appear as high up the SERP (Search Engine Results Page) as possible. It’s a very tricky discipline, but incredibly important for almost any businesses’ concerns in today’s digital world. For a full examination of SEO in theory and practice, check out one of our lessons on the subject.

name: Search Engine Results Page (SERP)
description: The Search Engine Results Page (SERP) is the page of listings displayed by a search engine following a user's keyword query. Appearing at the top of the SERP is the objective of Search Engine Optimisation (SEO).

name: Search Results Page (SRP)
description: The list of results that a search returns in response to a specific word or phrase query. On a retailer’s site it tends to be a list page

name: Second Party Data
description: Audience data shared between two parties, i.e. first party data made available for a media partner’s use.

name: Secondary Navigation
description: Navigation structure that appears after the first hover/click on primary navigation

name: SEM
description: Search Engine Marketing, or ‘SEM’ is the process of marketing a business using paid advertisements to increase visibility on search engine results pages (or SERPs). It is also called Paid Search and sometimes referred to as CPC (cost-per-click) or PPC (pay-per-click) marketing, because most search ads are sold on a CPC/PPC basis.

name: Shopping Campaigns
description: Automatically generated, image-based search ads for individual products. A shopping campaign ad provides an image of the product searched and a link to the e-commerce site beneath. These ads are only available to AdWords users who also have Google Merchant Center accounts.

name: Short codes
description: These are shortened telephone numbers that are designed to be memorable. They are usually used by marketers for SMS and MMS responses to campaigns.

name: Showrooming
description: The consumer practice of visiting a bricks & mortar store to view a product before buying it online e.g. due to lower price, wider selection/varieties, more convenient delivery

name: Site-Centric Data
description: Site usage data captured at the individual site level by web analytics companies such as Google Analytics and Omniture, or by research companies who want to compare sites. It can be measured in two ways:↵1)Log-file analysis - A web server logs the IP address of any user who requests a page. This data can be analysed by third parties at a later date. This approach is problematic because search engine spiders can request pages too.↵2)Tag and tracking code-based systems - Companies now attach a JavaScript tag to each page of their site. This fires when the page is requested and instructs the server to fire a cookie and a 1x1 pixel. This allows companies to identify unique users, but cookie deletion can skew results.

name: Sitemap
description: Sitemaps are lists of all the pages and resources within a website. There are two forms of sitemap: XML sitemaps, which are designed to be read by search engines, and HTML sitemaps, which are human readable lists of website content. XML sitemaps are useful because they allow the search engines to index site content hidden behind forms and content not composed in HTML, such as Flash content.

name: Skippable Ad
description: A video ad (usually pre-roll) which can be skipped after a fixed period of time. In the case of YouTube, this is usually 5 seconds. This has given rise to a change in video ad production as the brand must make an impact earlier in the ad to secure attention.

name: Social Plugins
description: Clickable buttons which allow a user to 'like' or 'share' content to a social network without leaving the site on which the content is hosted.

name: Sort
description: The feature that enables a shopper to re-order the products on the list page – usually set across the entire retailer’s website e.g. alphabetical, price, rating

name: Spear- fishing
description: A shopper search behaviour when a shopper searches for a specific item (rather than navigating). This will be higher for repeat purchases/returning customers than first-time buyers

name: SSP (Supply Side Platform)
description: A technology which enables sellers to locate the highest prices for their ad inventory within multiple ad exchanges.

name: Stack
description: See 'Technology Stack'

name: Sub-URL
description: A folder within a subdomain, usually expressed as a new web page within a website. Sub-URLs can be identified by the presence of a forward slash after the top-level domain of the URL, e.g. www.sports.site.co.uk/rugby.

name: Subdomain
description: A section of a larger domain (i.e. website).  The subdomain name is often the domain name with a new prefix to denote a different category or section of the domain, e.g. www.sports.site.co.uk if the domain name is www.site.co.uk.

name: Subscription Funded
description: A television funding model pioneered in the age of cable TV by companies such as HBO. The viewer pays a fixed subscription fee for access to a given channel, and this fee is used to fund the channel's content production efforts. This model has successfully made the transition online through companies such as Netflix.

name: Supplemental Index
description: An additional index containing web content that a search engine has flagged as being duplicated from elsewhere. Results in the supplemental index will not be returned on a SERP, but the user may then be offered the opportunity to view the data.

name: TAB
description: The Asset Bank or TAB is the single trusted source of all Unilever global & local final assets.

name: Targeting
description: The act of ensuring that ads are shown to a specific audience, compared to the mass broadcast advertising of the past.

name: Top-Down
description: The breaking down, or apart, of a system to gain insight into the sub-categories or components that make it up.

name: Tracking Tags/Action Tags
description: These come in several forms, including 'Image Tags', 'Iframe Tags', 'JavaScript Tags', and 'Click Tags'. The most common and basic type is an image tag, which is a 1x1 clear pixel incorporated into a web page by a browser when it renders the page for a user. This pixel lets the media agency ad server know that an action has been taken by the user. A cookie is also sent with this pixel, and this enables the media agency ad server to confirm that the action has been taken as a result of marketing activity on the media owner's site. It also enables the media agency to cross-reference the user with users who clicked or viewed the advertising.

name: Trading Desk
description: A manned layer of expertise, data and insights that provides additional targeting capability (and value) to Demand Side Platforms (DSPs). Trading desks were originally unique to agency holding companies, but they can now be found within media agencies themselves, media owners and even advertisers.

name: Trafficking sheet
description: Document authored by the media agency that provides scheduling information (and other pertinent campaign instructions, i.e. frequency capping) for the media owner. Usually delivered with the creative tags for the campaign.

name: Transmedia Planning
description: A planning approach first articulated by Faris Yakob in which planners construct an evolving, non-linear brand story designed to unfold across multiple platforms. Elements of the story are largely self-contained, allowing the user to participate in and contribute to the story.  Each element of the story must be appropriate for the platform in which it is housed, differentiating this approach from media neutral planning.

name: Trendwatch
description: Trendwatch is an algorithm developed by PDC analysts. Trendwatch can validate expected trends, analyze how trends move across the world, and predict which trends are most likely to take off next in the world of packaging, recipes, or fragrance.

name: Tumblr
description: A microblogging community owned by Yahoo. In the context of SEO, Tumblr blogs often repost content from other websites without permission, but this is unlikely to cause to the originating site to be penalised for duplication.

name: TV Commerce
description: Television Commerce leverages the interactivity of modern connected TVs by enabling viewers to purchase items on or through their televisions, and it is being trialled in several forms. The first is the addition of purchase buttons to new remote controls that allow you to buy products as they appear on TV programmes. Another form currently being trialled by American Express is the creation of t-commerce apps for connected televisions that are housed on connected TVs' desktops. A third form is the creation of smartphone and tablet apps designed to synchronise with TV programmes and launch interactive catalogues of products featured in them.

name: TVC
description: TVC is an acronym for Television Commercial.

name: UGC
description: UGC is an acronym for User Generated Content. This is any content made by users that can be uploaded to the web for the purposes of consumption, sharing, criticism or collaboration.  It can be anything from a review or blog post to a short film or even a novel. Social media channels have been instrumental in the distribution and promotion of user generated content, from YouTube to blogging services. As such, brands have been understandably keen to encourage users to generate UGC on their behalf, with varying degrees of success.

name: UGC (User Generated Content)
description: Any content made by users that can be uploaded to the web for the purposes of consumption, sharing, criticism or collaboration.  It can be anything from a review or blog post to a short film or even a novel. Social media channels have been instrumental in the distribution and promotion of user generated content, from YouTube to blogging services. As such, brands have been understandably keen to encourage users to generate UGC on their behalf, with varying degrees of success.

name: User Experience (UX)
description: How a shopper experiences the website. Combined experience of ease-of-use, design, usability and general look & feel

name: User Generated Content
description: Any content made by users that can be uploaded to the web for the purposes of consumption, sharing, criticism or collaboration.  It can be anything from a review or blog post to a short film or even a novel. Social media channels have been instrumental in the distribution and promotion of user generated content, from YouTube to blogging services. As such, brands have been understandably keen to encourage users to generate UGC on their behalf, with varying degrees of success.

name: User Generated Content (UGC)
description: Any content made by users that can be uploaded to the web for the purposes of consumption, sharing, criticism or collaboration.  It can be anything from a review or blog post to a short film or even a novel. Social media channels have been instrumental in the distribution and promotion of user generated content, from YouTube to blogging services. As such, brands have been understandably keen to encourage users to generate UGC on their behalf, with varying degrees of success.

name: User Interface (UI)
description: The visible graphic design of a website with which a shopper interacts. It is through this that the shopper controls their shopper journey

name: User-Centric Data
description: Involves the recruitment of a representative sample of internet users whose online activity is recorded and then used to infer the activity of a much larger group. The main way this is achieved is by users downloading toolbars from companies like Google, but research companies also invite users to download software which performs the same function in exchange for incentives such as free antivirus software or prize draws.

name: UTM Tags
description: A series of tags added on to the end of a standard URL. These are used for tracking where visitors clicked to reach your site, and are useful for monitoring the performance of marketing assets.

name: Vary Http Header
description: HTML code placed in the header of a page which indicates that different versions of the page may be served to different users. For example, different versions of a website served to the user depending on whether they are accessing through a mobile or desktop device.

name: Vertical
description: Synonymous with 'specialised' rather than 'niche' (although some niche channels do feature), a vertical channel is one with a specific focus, e.g. travel, finance, beauty, fitness, automotive, etc. Audience sizes in vertical channels can be enormous, but more often than not they are smaller than the offerings of 'broad' channels, e.g. YouTube, Facebook, men's magazines, etc. However, vertical channels tend to have more engaged audiences who are in theory more likely to respond to the targeted advertising found therein.  Consequently, CPMs for ads with vertical content providers can be very high.

name: Viewability
description: A new metric for ascertaining whether an ad with a dynamic component (e.g. video) has been seen. The industry standard is 50% of pixels in view for a minimum of one second.

name: Viewable Impression
description: A single digital ad that has the opportunity to be seen. According to the current industry criteria for a standard display ad unit, an ad is considered viewable if 50% of pixels are within the consumer’s rendered window for a minimum of one second – the time required for a consumer to understand that the unit is a piece of advertising.

name: Watermark
description: The act of incorporating additional information into an image or other content in such a way that it is difficult to remove. This information could be as obvious as a brand logo, or could even be completely invisible to the human eye. The aim of a watermark is to discourage the content from being appropriated by others and used without permission.

name: Web server
description: The generic name for computers that host websites and web content. Web servers deliver this content over the internet on request to 'clients', which in this case are web browsers.

name: Webrooming
description: The consumer practice of researching products online before buying them in a physical store. This often takes place in real-time in the store as a shopper searches for ratings and reviews and price comparison. It does not always take place on the website of the retailer who’s shop they are in and ultimately purchase with

name: Webview
description: An app development protocol which enables developers to display web content within their apps, turning them into miniature web browsers in their own right, albeit with quite limited functionality.

name: Whitelist
description: A list of web entities in whose properties an advertiser has agreed that their content can be displayed.

name: Wi-Fi (Also WLAN)
description: This is the name for the technology that allows devices to wirelessly send and receive information over a computer network. Before Wi-Fi, devices had to be hardwired into a network.

name: Wi-Fi Positioning System (WPS)
description: WPS is a term used to describe a the use of Wi-Fi as a positioning technology. WPS may be combined with cell phone tower triangulation and GPS to provide reliable and accurate position data under a wide range of conditions, including those where GPS signals may be intermittent or inadequate such as among tall buildings and indoors.

name: Wiki
description: A wiki is simply a website (usually a knowledge resource) that users can contribute to and edit online. The most famous example of a wiki site is Wikipedia, but there are many more. Wikis are a form of socialised knowledge sharing, and they have been incredibly successful.

name: World Wide Web
description: A web of interlinked resources composed in HyperText Markup Language and accessed via the Internet using the HyperText Transfer Protocol. Both the protocol and the markup language were invented by Sir Tim Berners-Lee, then a research fellow at the CERN particle physics laboratory, in order to enable his colleagues to keep up with the rapid pace of information updates throughout the facility. The project went online in 1990 and grew to become arguably the most significant innovation of the late 20th century bar the Internet itself. Its popularity is such that it is now synonymous with the Internet, but it is in fact only one of many ways of retrieving and submitting information over the Internet.

name: Yandex
description: Russia's most popular search engine (ranked the 20th most popular site worldwide by Alexa) founded by Arkady Volozh, Arkady Borkovsky and Ilya Segalovich and launched in September 1997. Like Google and Baidu, Yandex is advertiser-funded, and its enormous profits have enabled the company to expand into Turkey, Ukraine, Kazakhstan, and Belarus. It has also diversified its offering to include maps, social networking, a browser, music downloads, an e-commerce payment platform, and an English version of the company's search engine. The name of the company is a play on 'index'. The Russian word for 'I' is 'Ya', hence 'Yandex'.

name: Yield Optimisation
description: The process of re-allocating budgets from the lower-performing ad formats/placements to the higher performing ad formats/placements, to improve the overall yield of an ad campaign.
